docs.title: How to Register
docs.text: You can read about the domains JSON file structure here.

docs.title: Guides
docs.text:
• Cloudflare Pages
  • Discord Domain Verification
  • GitHub Pages
  • GitHub Pages Domain Verification
  • Hashnode Blogs
  • Railway
  • Replit
  • Render
  • DanBot Hosting
  • Other Services

docs.title: Vercel
docs.text: You will encounter a domain ownership verification issue when using Vercel so it will not will work with our domains. It is recommended to use GitHub Pages, Railway or Cloudflare Pages instead.

docs.title: Setting up Cloudflare Pages with is-a-dev subdomain
docs.text: This guide will walk you through the process of setting up a Cloudflare Pages site and pointing your is-a.dev subdomain to it.

docs.title: Create a Cloudflare Pages Site
docs.text: First, you'll need to create a site on Cloudflare Pages. Follow the instructions in the Cloudflare Pages Getting Started Guide.

docs.title: Point your subdomain to your Cloudflare Pages site
docs.text: Next, you'll need to point your is-a.dev subdomain to your Cloudflare Pages site. Follow the instructions in the Cloudflare Pages Custom Domains Guide. Only follow the "Add a custom domain" section, then return to this guide for the next steps.

docs.title: Create the Domain File
docs.text:
In the domains directory, create a new JSON file for your subdomain (domains/<subdomain>.json) and submit a pull request. This file should contain the following:

{
    "owner": {
        "username": "your-github-username",
        "email": "your-email@gmail.com"
    },
    "record": {
        "CNAME": "your-sitename.pages.dev"
    }
}

docs.title: Your site should be live!
docs.text: If you have followed all the steps correctly, then your site should be live after your pull request has been merged.

docs.title: Setting up DanBot Hosting with is-a.dev subdomain
docs.text: This guide will walk you through the process of setting up a DanBot Hosting site and pointing your is-a.dev subdomain to it.

docs.title: Getting Proxy IP
docs.text:
Execute the following command in DanBot Hosting Discord server in the #commands channel. 

dbh!server proxy

You will get a reply like this:

If you are on free plan, choose any US proxy or you can use the Donator Proxy If you are a Donator, then note the IP address of the proxy you chose.

docs.title: Creating the domain file
docs.text:
Create a JSON file inside domains directory (domains/<subdomain>.json) with the following content and submit a pull request: 

{
    "description": "Describe the use of this subdomain",
    "repo": "https://github.com/<github-username>/<github-repository>",
    "owner": {
        "username": "<github-username>",
        "email": "<email@address>",
        "twitter": "<twitter-username>"
    },
    "record": {
        "A": [
            "proxy-ip-here"
        ]
    }
}
Note: In the owner section, you can add any social media handle, such as Discord. If you add another social media account, you can omit the email and Twitter fields. However, the GitHub username is mandatory.

docs.title: Configuring
docs.text:
After the pull request is merged, get your server ID by running this command: 

dbh!server list

You will get a reply like this:

Note down the server ID, then execute following command:

docs.title: Setting up Discord domain connection with your is-a.dev domain
Get your verification string
docs.text:
1. Open your Discord app and press Settings.

  2. Open the Connections section.

  3. Press the View more button.

  4. Click on the domain button (the globe icon).

  5. In the field that appears type your is-a.dev domain name (e.g. example.is-a.dev).

  6. Copy the verification string.

docs.title: Create the domain file
docs.text:
Create a JSON file inside the domains/ directory called domains/_discord.example.json with the following content:

{
    "owner": {
        "username": "github-username",
        "email": "email@address"
    },
    "record": {
        "TXT": "discord-verification-string"
    }
}

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: After your pull request has been merged, repeat the steps to get the verification string and press the Verify button. If it shows any error such as Unable to verify your domain, try waiting a few minutes (sometimes up to 24 hours) as the DNS might have not been updated yet.

docs.title: Domains JSON file
docs.text: To register a subdomain, you need to create a new JSON file in the domains directory through a pull request. For example, to register example.is-a.dev, you would create a file named example.json in the domains directory. The full path would be domains/example.json.

docs.title: Filename
docs.text:
Note: You can include . (dots) in your filename to register a sub-subdomain (e.g., blog.example.is-a.dev). However, each segment of your subdomain must meet the following criteria:

The filename:

  • Must be alphanumeric, in lowercase, with dashes as separators.
  • Must be at least 2 characters.
  • Must have a .json file extension.

docs.title: Examples of Invalid Filenames
docs.text:
• a.json (filename is less than 2 characters)
  • A.json (filename contains uppercase letters)
  • a..json (filename contains consecutive dots)
  • .a.json (filename starts with a dot)
  • a .json (filename contains a space)
  • a$.json (filename contains a non-alphanumeric character)
  • a.json.json (filename contains more than one .json extension)

docs.title: Examples of Valid Filenames
docs.text:
All the filenames below meet all the criteria. The reason in parentheses is just an example of one of the criteria they meet.

  • ab.json (at least 2 characters long)
  • example.json (alphanumeric and in lowercase)
  • blog.example.json (includes dots to register a sub-subdomain)
  • my-blog.json (uses dashes as separators, which is recommended)

docs.title: Example JSON File
docs.text:
domains/docs.json 

{
  "description": "Documentation for is-a-dev",
  "repo": "https://github.com/is-a-dev/docs",
  "owner": {
    "username": "is-a-dev",
    "email": "hello@maintainers.is-a.dev"
  },
  "record": {
    "URL": "https://www.is-a.dev/docs"
  }
}

docs.title: owner (required)
docs.text:
You need to specify some information about yourself here. This is so that you can be contacted if required. In the owner object, the fields username and email are required. You can add more information in this object if you want. 

{
  "owner": {
    "username": "<github-username>",
    "email": "<email@address>"
  }
}

docs.title: description
docs.text: Describe your domain name and your usage. This is purely for documentation purpose and is optional.

docs.title: repo
docs.text: This is a link to your website repository or your github account. This is purely for documentation purpose and is optional.

docs.title: record (required)
docs.text:
This section is where you specify the DNS records. The supported types are:

  • CNAME
  • A
  • AAAA
  • URL
  • MX
  • TXT

Below are some examples for the given record types:

  • CNAME record: This must be a hostname (something.tld). It cannot be used in conjunction with any other record types. This is typically used to map your domain to a specific server. 
    {
  "record": {
    "CNAME": "<github-username>.github.io"
  }
}
  • A record: This must be a list of IPv4 addresses. These addresses point your domain to a specific server. 
    {
  "record": {
    "A": [
      "192.0.2.1",
      "198.51.100.1",
      "203.0.113.1"
    ]
  }
}
  • AAAA record: This must be a list of IPv6 addresses. Like the A record, these addresses point your domain to a specific server. 
    {
  "record": {
    "AAAA": [
      "2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334",
      "2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7335",
      "2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7336"
    ]
  }
}
  • URL record: This redirects your domain to another URL. 
    {
  "record": {
    "URL": "https://my-other-website.com"
  }
}
  • MX record: This must be a list of hostnames. These hostnames specify the mail servers that handle emails for your domain. 
    {
  "record": {
    "MX": [
      "mx1.improvmx.com",
      "mx2.improvmx.com"
    ]
  }
}
  • TXT record: This can be either a single string or a list of strings. TXT records are often used for various purposes, such as verifying domain ownership and ensuring email security. 
    {
  "record": {
    "TXT": "Hello World!"
  }
}

    {
  "record": {
    "TXT": ["Hello", "World!"]
  }
}

docs.title: Which records are supported?
docs.text: We support the following records: - A - AAAA - CNAME - MX - TXT - URL (Redirection)

docs.title: Why does my domain still redirect to the is-a-dev website?
docs.text: This usually occurs due to the cache of your browser becoming invalid and clearing your browser's cache should solve this issue.

docs.title: How long will it take for my PR to get merged?
docs.text: When we get into it. We always want you to wait for as short as possible. But maintainers cannot always be online. We have school and work, this is just a side project. Just be patient and we'll get to it as soon as possible! For a chance for a quicker review, send your PR in ⁠pull-requests.

docs.title: Which services do you support?
docs.text: We support almost all services except Vercel. For example: Github Pages and Cloudflare Pages.

docs.title: Can I create nested subdomains? (sub-sub domains)
docs.text: Yes, you can! Simply create a file such as blog.example.json and follow the same guidelines as you would while registering example.json. Please note in order to have blog.example.is-a.dev, you must also own example.is-a.dev.

docs.title: How can I edit my domain?
docs.text: You can edit your domain's JSON file and submit a pull request to edit your domain.

docs.title: How can I delete my domain?
docs.text: You can delete your domain's JSON file and submit a pull request to delete your domain.

docs.title: Can I be a maintainer/join the team?
docs.text: No, we handpick every member of our team. You can increase your chances of being chosen by helping out people in our help forums.

docs.title: I have accidentally leaked sensitive information in my PR, how can I get my PR deleted?
docs.text: If your PR has not been merged, you can DM William however, if it has been merged already, then there is nothing we can do about it unfortunately.

docs.title: My DNS records are not updating even after 48 hours, what should I do?
docs.text: Please open a help thread via any of our help channels and we will look into it.

docs.title: Can I use my domain for a minecraft server?
docs.text: Sure, but it needs to be a nested subdomain (mc.example.is-a.dev). You would normally use a A record for this.

docs.title: How can I make changes to my is-a.dev subdomain?
docs.text:
1. Open your JSON file: Navigate to the domains directory in your local repository and open the JSON file corresponding to your subdomain (domains/<subdomain>.json).

  2. Make your changes: Edit the JSON file (or delete) to reflect the changes you want to make.

  3. Commit your changes: Once you've made your changes, commit them to your local repository.

  4. Push your changes: Push your changes to your forked repository on GitHub.

  5. Submit a Pull Request: Go to your forked repository on GitHub and open a pull request.

  6. Wait for your PR to be merged: After you have submitted your pull request, wait for it to be reviewed and merged. Once your pull request has been merged, your changes should be live!

Note: Make sure to monitor your PR for reviews in case some changes are requested. Also note that it can take up to 48 hours in some rare cases for your changes to take effect after your PR is merged.

docs.title: Setting up GitHub pages with is-a.dev subdomain
docs.text: This guide will walk you through the process of setting up a GitHub Pages site and pointing your is-a.dev subdomain to it.

docs.title: Creating a GitHub Pages repository
docs.text: First, you'll need to create a site on GitHub Pages. Follow the instructions in the GitHub Pages Getting Started Guide.

docs.title: Creating the domain file
docs.text:
Create a JSON file inside domains directory (domains/<subdomain>.json) with the following content and submit a pull request: 

{
    "description": "Describe the use of this subdomain",
    "repo": "https://github.com/<github-username>/<github-repository>",
    "owner": {
        "username": "<github-username>",
        "email": "<email@address>",
        "twitter": "<twitter-username>"
    },
    "record": {
        "CNAME": "<github-username>.github.io"
    }
}

docs.title: Configuring
docs.text:
• After the pull request is merged, you may see a 404 error on <subdomain>.is-a.dev or the wrong site. To fix this, go to your GitHub pages repository's Settings > GitHub pages > Custom Domain and add <subdomain>.is-a.dev in the given field. Only do this after your pull request is merged.
  • Check the Enforce HTTPS checkbox below the custom domain input.
  • Wait some time and your site should be live!

docs.title: Verify your is-a.dev Domain with GitHub Pages
Get your verification string
docs.text:
1. Open GitHub, press on your profile icon on the top right, and press Settings.
  1. Press Pages.
  1. Press Add a domain.
  1. In the field that appears, type your is-a.dev domain name (e.g. myname.is-a.dev) and press Add domain.
  1. Copy the hostname and the verification string.

docs.title: Create the domain file
docs.text:
Create a JSON file inside the domains/ directory called domains/hostname.json using the hostname you copied in step 5 with the following content and submit a pull request:

{
    "owner": {
        "username": "<github-username>",
        "email": "<email@address>"
    },
    "record": {
        "TXT": "<github-verification-string>"
    }
}

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: After your pull request has been merged, repeat the steps to get the verification string and press the Verify button. If it shows any error such as Unable to verify your domain, try waiting a few minutes (sometimes up to 24 hours) as the DNS change might not have reflected on the DNS server.

docs.title: Hashnode Blog
docs.text:
When you create your hashnode blog, hashnode provides a free hashnode.dev subdomain for you. However, you can set up your own is-a.dev subdomain.

In this guide, you will learn how to accomplish this.

  1. Log in to your Hashnode account.

  2. Click on your avatar at the bottom-left corner of the page on desktop or top-right corner on mobile.

  3. Click on the Blog Dashboard option from the popup modal to access your blog's dashboard.

  4. Navigate to the Domain tab and enter your domain without the www or https:// prefix in the text field provided. Then click on the Update button to proceed.

  5. Go to your fork of the is-a-dev/register repository, edit your subdomain's JSON file, make sure you remove any old records, then add this and submit a PR: 

    "CNAME": "hashnode.network"

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Once done, your hashnode blog is setup to use your subdomain, all you have to do is wait some time for the DNS to propogate. These changes could take from 1 hour to around 48 hours, so please be patient. It'll most likely be ready within a hour.

Once the DNS has propagated, you can start enjoying your Hashnode blog with your sweet .is-a.dev subdomain!

docs.title: Need More Help?
docs.text:
If you encounter any issues or need further assistance, consider the following resources:

  • Hashnode Domain Mapping Guide: This support article provides detailed instructions on mapping your domain in Hashnode.
  • Hashnode Support Center: For more general help related to Hashnode, visit their Support Center.

Please note that is-a.dev is not affiliated with Hashnode. If you're experiencing issues with your Hashnode blog, please seek help through Hashnode's support channels. We are unable to assist with Hashnode-specific issues.

docs.title: Setting up other services with is-a.dev
Setting up records
docs.text: Read the domain file structure and setup the records accordingly.

docs.title: Configuring your server
docs.text:
After the pull request is merged, configure your server (apache, nginx, etc.) to work with <subdomain>.is-a.dev. If you are unsure how to configure your server, you can create an issue for support.

You should also, include <subdomain>.is-a.dev in your ssl certificate to get rid of certificate errors.

docs.title: Getting the CNAME Record
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the dashboard
  2. Navigate to the project.
  3. Navigate to the service.
  4. Switch to the Settings tab.
  5. Click on + Custom Domain button.
  6. Enter the is-a.dev subdomain you want to use.
  7. Copy the Value field.
  8. Go to the register site.
  9. Choose CNAME record type from the dropdown menu.
  10. Choose your desired subdomain.
  11. Enter the value from clipboard in the Record Value field.
  12. Click on the Submit Query button.
  13. Wait for your pull request to be merged and the DNS records to update.

If the PR has been merged, the DNS records will be updated in a few minutes. If the PR has been merged but the DNS records haven't updated and you have waited 48 hours, open a GitHub issue or a help thread in the is-a.dev discord server.

docs.title: Setting up Render with is-a.dev Subdomain
docs.text: This guide will walk you through the process of setting up a Render deployment and pointing your is-a.dev subdomain to it.

docs.title: Creating a Render Service
docs.text: First, you'll need to create a service on Render. Follow the instructions in the Render Docs.

docs.title: Creating the Domain File
docs.text:
Create a JSON file inside the domains directory (domains/<subdomain>.json) with the following content and submit a pull request: 

{
    "description": "Describe the use of this subdomain",
    "repo": "https://github.com/<github-username>/<github-repository>",
    "owner": {
        "username": "<github-username>",
        "email": "<email@address>",
        "twitter": "<twitter-username>"
    },
    "record": {
        "A": [
            "216.24.57.1"
        ]
    }
}
Note: In the owner section, you can add any social media handle, such as Discord. If you add another social media account, you can omit the email and Twitter fields. However, the GitHub username is mandatory.

docs.title: Configuring Render
docs.text:
• After the pull request is merged, you may need to configure your Render service to use the new subdomain. Go to your Render service's dashboard.
  • Navigate to Settings > Custom Domains and add <subdomain>.is-a.dev in the given field.
  • Render will provide a verification step, usually requiring you to add a DNS record. This step should be skipped if your subdomain is already pointing to Render's IP address (216.24.57.1).

docs.title: Final Steps
docs.text:
• Wait for the DNS changes to propagate. This can take from a few minutes to a couple of hours.
  • Your Render service should now be accessible at <subdomain>.is-a.dev.

docs.title: Setting up Replit with your is-a.dev subdomain
Creating a project
docs.text: Follow the instructions in the Replit Workspace Guide on how to create a project.

docs.title: Connect your repl to your is-a.dev subdomain
docs.text:
Follow the instructions in the Replit Custom Domains Guide.

Only follow the "Connecting your domain to your repl" section, then return to this guide for the next steps.

docs.title: Creating the domain file
docs.text:
Create a JSON file inside domains directory (domains/<subdomain>.json) with the following content:

Note: Do not add any TXT records, even if Replit instructs you to do so.

{
    "owner": {
        "username": "<github-username>",
        "email": "<email@address>",
        "twitter": "<twitter-username>"
    },
    "record": {
        "CNAME": "<siteid>.id.repl.co"
    }
}

docs.title: Configuring
docs.text: • After your pull request has been merged into the main repository you should be able to visit your new is-a.dev domain and it should show you your replit site, if it doesn't then you have configured your domain wrong.

docs.title: Resources
docs.text: This page provides a collection of resources to help you understand key concepts related to domain management, such as DNS, records, and more.

docs.title: Asking For Help
docs.text:
• How do I ask a good question? - A guide on how to ask a good question by Stack Overflow.
  • How To Ask Questions The Smart Way - A long and comprehensive guide on asking questions the smart way by Eric Steven Raymond and Rick Moen.

docs.title: JSON
docs.text:
• JSON for Beginners - JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) Explained in Plain English by Tapas Adhikary.
  • JSON Formatter - A JSON formatter and validator.
  • JSON Explained - A video on JSON by Hostinger Academy.

docs.title: Domain Name System (DNS)
docs.text:
• What is DNS? - A beginner-friendly introduction to DNS from Cloudflare.
  • How DNS Works - A fun and colorful explanation of how DNS works using a comic.
  • DNS Explained - A video explanation of DNS on YouTube.

docs.title: DNS Records
docs.text:
• Understanding DNS Record Types - A guide to different types of DNS records from Cloudflare.
  • DNS Record Types - An explanation of common DNS record types using a comic.
  • DNS Records Explained - A video explanation of DNS records.

docs.title: Git and GitHub
docs.text:
• The Simple Guide to Git - A simple guide to Git without any deep shit.
  • Think Like a Git - A guide for understanding Git.

docs.title: Other
docs.text:
• How to Clear Browser Cache - A simple guide on clearing browser cache in popular browsers.
  • How HTTPS Works - An explanation of HTTPS using a comic.
